awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Power Optimization of Electro-Thermal Sytems (POETS) REU
awd_abstract_narration:
This new three-year Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site Program, located within the Engineering Research Center (ERC), Power Optimization of Electro-Thermal Systems (POETS), at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign will enhance the knowledge and skill-level of a diverse cohort of undergraduate students with limited access to research opportunities through empowering, hands-on and interdisciplinary research experiences in the area of thermal management of heat in mobile powered devices.  The POETS REU Site located within four institutions-the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Howard University, Stanford University and the University of Arkansas, will train and mentor a diverse set of undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented minority groups with a multidisciplinary, systems approach. The program takes an intergenerational approach where the REU students will be mentored by more experienced researchers and they will serve as leaders and mentors to high school students, gaining experiences so they better see themselves as on a journey toward the expertise they will need as successful researchers. After the completion of the summer experience the REU students will the POETS team will strive to develop a long-term relationship, keeping the students informed about opportunities that arise, thus addressing the goal of solidifying REU student interest in graduate research.        

Each summer, 10 students will be hosted by the four POETS ERC institutions where they will address the timely and critical problem impeding development of many mobile systems - the thermal constraints that arise from increased power densities.  Through their projects the students will be able to readily see the connections and interactions between different disciplines and research teams as they engage in their own research.  Additionally, the REU students will be trained in critical elements of leadership, safety, ethics, teamwork, and outreach.  Their communication abilities, both written and oral will be developed as they prepare and present their research results as well as prepare a draft of an REU graduate fellowship application. The impact of this Site will be to excite, empower, and educate students, and to enable/inspire them to pursue advanced study and STEM careers.

por.por_cntn:
Our students' research experiences are designed around ongoing projects funded by the NSF Engineering Research Center (ERC) Power Optimization of Electro-Thermal Systems (POETS). POETS's objective is to increase the power density of current mobile electrified systems to push its electrical capability beyond the state of the art. To address this problem, POETS is developing novel approaches to control and tolerate high thermal power flow in solid-state devices. This will require breakthroughs in (1) materials and fabrication methods, (2) electrical and thermal management strategies, and (3) optimization and controls approaches. A systems-level approach necessitates breaking down the silos of material science, mechanical engineering and electrical engineering in order to co-design, multi-dimensional electrical systems. The center is based at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and partners with Howard University, Stanford University and University of Arkansas to drive this mission.

The POETS REU Site's goal is to create a pull into PhD programs due to attractive post-PhD careers, versus the traditional model of nudging students into these programs with a goal of "replicating faculty researchers."  We hypothesize that presenting students with and preparing them for a multitude of STEM careers with diverse examples can lead to increased attrition rates in STEM PhD programs. The POETS REU Site has created this "pull" by building, strengthening and supporting students? foundational and high-order knowledge in engineering disciplines (Aim 1) while broadening their skill set and experiences to prepare them for PhD STEM careers (Aim 2). In essence, we are building T-shaped REU students. Experiences gained at the individual university level will address Aim 1 and will consist of activities such as attending REU technical webinars, participating in team-based interdisciplinary projects, scientific communication training, etc. Experiences gained at the POETS center level will address Aim 2 through bi-weekly webinars throughout the summer to strengthen students' personal competences, assist with career planning and build a broad STEM network.

Over the last six years POETS recruited 57 highly diverse undergraduate students to engage in a 10-week summer program focused on interdisciplinary research in power optimization. Students strengthened their engineering skill set, increased their confidence to pursue a career in STEM, and engaged in a very positive summer experience. POETS' external evaluator determined that the 2018 - 2023 REU program met its key objectives. Many of our 2018-2023 REU Site alumni have not yet graduated, but of those who have ~50% are in STEM-relevant industry positions and ~45% are in graduate school pursuing PhDs and Master's degrees in STEM.

Improvement in students' engineering skills were measured through a pre- and post- program self-evaluation questionnaire. Nine out of ten students rated their engineering skills as significantly improved over the program including the students' ability to "read, interpret, and use research information," "develop a professional network," and "generally communicate their research." This validates that our approach to training students in research methodology and scientific communication is effective. Students were overall satisfied or very satisfied with the REU program's accommodations, stipend, lab placement and support provided by POETS staff and mentors. Post-program surveys also show that all students are interested in staying involved with STEM upon completion of their bachelor's degrees with a few interested in a MBA for a STEM entrepreneurship career. Nearly fifty percent of our students are interested in obtaining a STEM position in industry. Three-quarters of the surveyed students reported that they would like to pursue a Master's in STEM while two-thirds reported that they would like to purse a Ph.D. The evaluation also asked students several open-ended questions. Through these anonymous responses it can be seen that the POETS REU Site students have experienced positive changes in their confidence and motivation as well as developed an improved scientific identity. The impact the POETS REU Site has made on students so far is a promising milestone towards our long-term goal of transitioning these students into the STEM ecosystem. Overall, the POETS REU Site students gave over 75 research presentations between 2018 and 2023.  In addition, eight REU students have co-authored conference papers and/or co-presented conference talks at external venues with several additional papers in preparation.
